bibl.title: Letter from S.C. Mead to Merritte W. Ireland, June 22, 1922

div1.p: Mead hopes that the annuities will continue as long as Mabel Lazear and Jennie Carroll are in need.

div1.head: Letter from S.C. Mead to Merritte W. Ireland, June 22, 1922
div1.opener:
Copy
June 22, 1922.
Major-General M. W. Ireland,
Surgeon General, U. S. Army,
War Department, Washington, D.C.
Dear General Ireland:
div1.p:
Your courtesy in so promptly acknowledging my letter
relative to the annuity for Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear and Mrs. Jennie
H. Carroll, is greatly appreciated.

The same mail brought me a letter from Congressman
Anthony, very cordial in tone, advising that these items are in-
cluded in the Army Appropriation Bill for the year 1923, having
passed both the House and Senate, and undoubtedly will be agreed
to in conference.

It is our hope, of course, that the granting of these
annuities will continue at least so long as the financial condition
of the ladies in question renders them at all dependent thereon.
As a matter of personal opinion, I believe that the annuities should
be continued during their lives, irrespective of financial condi-
tions, because it is the only recognition which the Government of
Major-General Ireland, 2.
the United States has made of the historic self-sacrifice of
Dr. Lazear and Major Carroll in determining the cause and
therefore providing ground for the prevention of Yellow Fever.

Your letter has brought me a sense of personal pleasure
from the fact that you recollect our previous contact in connec-
tion with this matter in which we cooperated so actively in 1907
and 1908.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Secretary,
THE MERCHANTS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK. SCM. AD
